translated: Birth Stories
The Four-Part Collection
The Chapter on the Adulterer
The Birth Story of Brahmadatta
“The beggar goes to the king,
Brahmadatta, for a pair;
Whether he gets nothing or gets wealth,
such is the nature of begging.
They say that begging is crying,
for the Panchalas, lord of chariots;
He who rejects the begging,

analyzed: tam āhuḥ paṭirodana  mā mad dasasu rodanta
translated: they say that is the counter-crying.
Don’t let the Panchalas, well assembled, see me crying;
Either you or I will cry,
therefore I want to be alone.”
“I give you, brahmin, a thousand red cows,
with a bull as the leader;

original: Ariyo hi ariyassa kathaṁ na dajjā,
analyzed: ariyaḥ hi ariyassa katham na dajjā
translated: For an noble one, how could an noble one not give,

analyzed: sutvāna gāthā tava dhamma yuttā ati
translated: after hearing your verses connected with the Dhamma.”
The Birth Story of Brahmadatta, the third.
